We honor the servicemembers who lost their lives at #PearlHarbor and continue to honor the millions of servicemembers from different walks of life who served our country in the days and years that followed.

But as fact, slavery didn‚Äôt end with either Lincoln‚Äôs Proclamation on January 1, 1863 or General Grainer‚Äôs Army Order No. 3 for a part of Texas on June 19, 1865. 
https://t.co/de7BCseTap

It was, and remains, that only upon amending the US Constitution on Dec. 6, 1865 was slavery abolished in this country.  To be sure, a National Holiday to celebrate the end of slavery in America is a welcomed event regardless of the day chosen to do it.

Today marks 156 years since the abolishment of slavery in America by the ratification of the 13th Amendment,
While we celebrate Juneteenth as a National Holiday, it is undisputed that nothing happened on that day to end slavery.
